text:
Q: How do you disable the unused variable warnings coming out of GCC in third-party code I do not wish to edit? A:

You can prefix the variables with '(void)'. This can be useful if you don't have access to the build framework or you only want to affect a local change in behavior.

That is,

int main()
{
  int unused1;       // This will print warning
  int unused2;       // This will not print warning -
                     //                             |
  (void) unused2;    // <----------------------------
}

Compile:

g++ -Wall test.cc

Output:

test.cc: In function ‘int main()’:
test.cc:4:7: warning: unused variable ‘unused1’ [-Wunused-variable]
    4 |   int unused1;
      |       ^~~~~~~

Q: How to get matching data from another SQL table for two different columns: Inner Join and/or Union? A:

Using @philipxy's answer asker @LeviTonet came up with the following working query:

SELECT tblCLS.className,
    tblP.facilLname, tblP.facilFname, tblS.facilLname, tblS.facilFname
FROM (tbl_facilitatorClasses AS tblCLS
INNER JOIN tbl_facilitators AS tblP
ON tblCLS.primeFacil=tblP.facilID)
INNER JOIN tbl_facilitators AS tblS
ON tblCLS.secondFacil=tblS.facilID;

When performing multiple inner joins in MS Access parentheses are needed.

Q: What is VBV (Video Buffering Verifier) in H.264? A:

Explanation provided by aergistal is perfect, but if you are confused by the counter intuitiveness of this passage:

It's a bit counter-intuitive but a VBV underflow signals an encoder rate buffer overflow (video bitrate larger than the input rate) while a VBV overflow signals an encoder rate buffer underflow (video bitrate lower than input the rate).

You have to think of VBV from decoder's perspective. Let me clarify few terms here (assuming data transmission over network, as in, encoded data is transmitted over internet):

video bitrate - the rate at which decoder consumes bits from its buffer

input bitrate - rate at which decoder buffer is being filled. (as per our assumption, its' network bandwidth)

why decoder video bitrare is not constant: In reality decoder can't pull bits from its buffer at constant rate because some frames (I) are larger in size, thus decoder needs to pull more bits and some are smaller in size (P or B), requiring lesser number of bits, thus decoder's bitrate is variable by nature.

If we take an example of encoder encoding data at 10mbps and network provides 5mbps of bandwidth, here input bitrate becomes 5mpbs but video bitrate is not 10mbps as I said video bitrate is the rate of decoder pulling bits from it's buffer. So if decoder is pulling at lower speeds, video bitrate lower than input rate we get under underflow and video bitrate larger than input rate we get overflow.

Remember VBV is a mathematical model on encoder's side simulating how a decoder's buffer would behave.

So if anyone confused video bitrate to encoder's bitrate like me, the concept doesn't click in. Hope it helps someone.

Q: Powershell one-liner not working from cmd A:

Works for me

powershell -command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.IO.Compression.FileSystem; [System.IO.Compression.ZipFile]::ExtractToDirectory(\"c:/program/compressed.zip\",\"c:/program\")}"

from powershell /? we get -command "& { < command > }"

but the enclosed " are poison to the outer quotes thus need \" escaping

and now you have several alternate answers to avoid those internal "

NOTE this is the only native way to unzip on Windows 7 where I tested, but on Windows 10/11 I would use the simpler TAR to extract

TAR -m -xf compressed.zip if it was run in that folder or

cd /d c:\program & TAR -m -xf compressed.zip (other options are available as shown in answer

However TAR --help will not show you how to zip (tar -a) although it is possible. for basic choices see here https://stackoverflow.com/a/70011759/10802527 but you can use TAR to navigate between folders collecting files as it goes into one zip. What you may not be able do easily with TAR is combine (append) zips without temporary out's and in's.

I have found that to ADD REPLACE OR UPDATE a zip on Windows is not directly possible with Windows TAR. It has the same limitation as PowerShell has. You can extract one or more files but cannot easily add a single file to an existing zip format.

For this ability you need a cmd written exe file (zip-it) as described at https://stackoverflow.com/a/76690779/10802527

This can be done in a complex PowerShell command, but it is far easier and faster to write the exe version, rather than a ps1 one.

Q: join the tables using Laravel Query Builder to show country name by ID A:

Check the documentation on joins.

DB::table('T2')->join('T1', 'T1.id', '=', 'T2.id_column')->get();

Assuming that the column in T2 that has the T1 id is called id_column.
